thread.title: Eddie who? Carlton’s new forward cult hero
thread.title_full: Eddie who? Carlton’s new forward cult hero

title: Eddie who? Carlton’s new forward cult hero
text:
CARLTON may have lost Eddie Betts. 
But the Blues have found another talismanic forward in Darcy Vescio. 
And perhaps their new cult hero. 
Vescio, from the VWFL powerhouse Darebin, left the crowd salivating after a four-goal performance that wreaked of class. 
At half-time, after she’d booted a game-high three goals to put Carlton in front by 15 points, she was the name on everyone’s lips and perhaps everyone’s imminent badge purchase. 
As Patrick Dangerfield told Channel 7 after learning Vescio was a graphic designed by trade: “She might be making her own poster this week, I have a feeling.” 
Vescio’s first goal was also Carlton’s first — a record no one can take from the 166cm half forward. 
LOCK OUT: FANS VOTE WITH THEIR FEET 
The second came from the pocket. At a ruck contest, she guided the ball down to her deadly foot and slotted it through the goalposts before anyone had time to think. 
The third came when she got on the end of Carlton’s cleanest passage of play — a coast-to-coast goal which was signed, sealed and delivered by Carlton’s marquee star. 
“It was a team effort, I just finished off their hard work. I’m happy about it,” Vescio told Channel 7 post-match. 
“I think we just played with a lot of freedom and brought in our strengths into the game. Everyone just played a ripper and we played just as a team. It was unreal.” 
Vescio, like Betts, is a nightmare to match up on. Darcy Vescio kicked four goals. Source: Getty Images 
Play too tall and she’ll murder you at your feet. Play too small and she’ll defeat you in the air. 
Agile, explosive, crafty and dynamic, Vescio has the star power to match her marquee status. And she backed it up with her magic in the historic inaugural AFLW match. 
A big time player who took home the best on ground honours in Darebin’s 2016 flag, she again rose to the occasion. 
Her Darebin skipper Daisy Pearce remarked Vescio had been an “out and out star tonight, not just with her skills but in the air and at ground level”. 
For much of the match, Nicola Stevens — Collingwood’s first draft pick — was her opponent. 
If it weren’t for an ACL injury in 2014, Stevens would have more than likely earned marquee status. She’s no slouch, making Vescio’s feats all the more impressive. 
Like Betts, Vescio doesn’t need too much of the pill to have a profound effect on the result. At half time, it was six possessions for three goals. 
In the third term, it was a long run that will only show for one kick. But it involved a bounce, an error, a recovery and a 50 metre entry. 
Then it was a handball out of congestion that led to the first goal of the second half, a stand and deliver from her marquee sister Brianna Davey that gave the Blues a 20-point buffer. 
But not to be outdone, she booted the next major, an around the body snap from 30 metres that dribbled through with delight. Carlton’s Darcy Vescio led her team to victory. Picture: Wayne Ludbey Source: News Corp Australia 
Like a true star, it was a siren-to-siren performance. When lining up for her fifth she selflessly gave the ball off to her skipper Lauren Arnell, who was closer to goal. 
She missed, but it showed Vescio has equal spades of disciple and design. 
In front of a packed home crowd, Vescio loved every minute. 
“That was insane. Just the numbers, the crowd, the game — it was so fast and the girls did so well,” Vescio said. 
“The roar, we could hardly here anything out here. It was just amazing, hearing the crowd get up 
and about and that is what it is all about. We just want people to come and watch us play and see what we create.” 
And so for all the talk of the damage Collingwood star Mo Hope would inflict, Vescio emerged at the opposite end as the player most likely. 
A livewire forward is back at Carlton. 
Just don’t tell Adelaide. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
